case_name: Dattatreya Moreshwar Pangarkar v. State of Bombay

facts.text: Petition No. 683 of 1951 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution for writ of habeas corpus.

anchor.surface_text: ORGINAL JURISDICTION. Petition  No. 683 of 1951  under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for a writ in the nature of habeas companypus.

facts.text: Petitioner alleged to be in illegal detention in Baroda Central Prison.

anchor.surface_text: for the immediate release of the petitioner who is alleged to have been kept in illegal detention in Baroda Central Prison.

facts.text: Petitioner arrested on February 15, 1951 under order dated February 13, 1951 by District Magistrate, Surat under Preventive Detention Act, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: On February 15, 1951, the petitioner was arrested under an order made on February 13, 1951, by the then District Magistrate, Surat, in exercise of powers companyferred on him by the Preventive Detention Act, 1950.

facts.text: Copy of detention order served on petitioner at time of arrest.

anchor.surface_text: A companyy of the said order was served on the petitioner at the time of his ar- rest.

facts.text: Grounds of detention served on petitioner on February 15, 1951 as required by section 7 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: On the same date grounds of detention were served on the petitioner as required by section 7 of the Act.

facts.text: Grounds of detention stated it was not in public interest to disclose further facts.

anchor.surface_text: It was specifically mentioned in the grounds that it was number in the public interest to disclose further facts.

facts.text: Petitioner filed application in Bombay High Court under Article 226 complaining detention illegal.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner moved the High Court of Bombay under article 226 of the Constitution companyplaining that his detention was illegal and praying that he should be forthwith released.

facts.text: Petitioner urged in High Court that grounds were false, vague, fantastic and detention in bad faith.

anchor.surface_text: In that appli- cation one of the points urged was that the grounds in support of the detention were false, vague and fantastic and that the detention order was made in bad faith.

facts.text: Two affidavits filed on behalf of State in High Court in support of detention order.

anchor.surface_text: Two affida- vits were filed on behalf of the State in support of the detention order.

facts.text: Bombay High Court dismissed petitioner's application on April 17, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: That application was, on April 17, 1951, dismissed by the Bombay High Court.

facts.text: Advisory Board made report on April 5, 1951 stating sufficient cause for detention.

anchor.surface_text: In the meantime, the case of the petitioner was placed before the Advisory Board which on Aprils, 1951, made a report stating that in its opinion there was sufficient cause for the detention of the petitioner.

facts.text: Government decided on April 13, 1951 to confirm the detention order.

anchor.surface_text: this report of the Advisory Board was placed before the Govern- ment and, on April 13, 1951, the Government decided to companyfirm the order of detention.

facts.text: Confirmation decision communicated to District Magistrate, Surat on April 28, 1951 via confidential letter.

anchor.surface_text: This decision was, on April 28, 1951, companymunicated to the District Magistrate, Surat, in a companyfidential letter in the terms following --

facts.text: Confidential letter No. B.D. II/1042-D 11 Home Department Political Bombay Castle, To 28th April, 1951 confirmed detention order.

anchor.surface_text: Confidential letter No. B.D. II/1042-D  11  Home Department  Political  Bombay Castle, To 28th April, 1951. The District Magistrate, Surat. Subject-Preventive Detention Act, 1950- Review of detention orders issued under the--

facts.text: Letter signed by G. K. Kharkar for Secretary to the Government of Bombay, Home Department.

anchor.surface_text: Sd -G, K. Kharkar, for Secretary to the Government of Bom- bay, Home Department.

facts.text: G. K. Kharkar was Assistant Secretary authorized under rule 12 of Rules of Business under Article 166.

anchor.surface_text: Sri K. Kharkar who signed the letter for the Secretary to the Government of Bombay, Home Department, was at the time an Assistant Secretary and, as such, was, under rule 12 of the Rules of Business made by the Government of Bombay under article 166 of the Constitution, authorised to sign orders and instruments of the Government of Bombay.

facts.text: Affidavit filed by Venilal Tribhovandas Dehejia, Secretary to Government of Bombay, Home Department.

anchor.surface_text: According to the affidavit of Venilal Tribho- vandas Dehejia, Secretary to the Government of Bombay, Home Department, filed in answer to the present application,

facts.text: Court heard on March 27, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: 1952. March 27. The Court delivered judgment as fol- lows-- DAS J.

facts.text: Bawa Shiv Charan Singh as amicus curiae for petitioner.

anchor.surface_text: Bawa Shiv Charan Singh  amicus curiae  for the petition- er. C. Setalvad, Attorney-General for India  Jindra Lal, with him  for the respondents.

facts.text: C. Setalvad, Attorney-General for India for respondents.

anchor.surface_text: C. Setalvad, Attorney-General for India  Jindra Lal, with him  for the respondents.

facts.text: Petitioner's counsel confined arguments to two grounds: failure to specify period in confirmation under s.11(1) and confirmation not in name of Governor.

facts.text: Supplementary petition filed complaining grounds false, vague, but not pressed.

anchor.surface_text: Although a supplementary petition has been filed in this Court companyplaining that the grounds supplied to him are false, vague, lacking in particulars and insufficient to enable the petitioner to make an effective representation against the order of detention, it has number, however, been pressed before us

holdings.text: On a proper construction of section 11(1), a specification of the period of continuation of the detention is not necessary.

anchor.surface_text: In my judgment, on a proper construction of section 11 1 , a specification of the period of continuation of the detention is number necessary, however desirable one may companysider it to be.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Grammatical analysis separates confirmation and continuation powers; continuation automatic post-confirmation; temporary nature of Act limits duration; precedents like Gopalan confirm no indefinite detention.

holdings.text: Omission to comply with Article 166 does not render executive action a nullity.

anchor.surface_text: an omission to companyply with those provisions does number render the executive action a nullity. Therefore, all that the procedure established by law re- quires is that the appropriate Government must take a deci- sion

holdings.reasoning_summary: Provisions directory for public duties unless conferring private rights; no prejudice to detenu; loses immunity but action valid if proved by proper authority; follows Federal Court precedent.

holdings.text: There has been no breach of procedure established by law; detention valid.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, there has been, in the circumstances of this case, numberbreach of the procedure established by law and the present detention of the petitioner cannot be called in question.

holdings.reasoning_summary: All procedural steps under PDA followed; challenges to s.11(1) and Art.166 rejected.

holdings.text: Non-specification of period under s.11(1) does not make order a nullity in temporary statute.

anchor.surface_text: I am inclined to hold that number-specifica- tion of the further period in an order under section 11 II  of the Act does number make the order of detention a nullity.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Temporary Act implies continuation till expiry; s.13 allows earlier release; no prejudice as review expected.

holdings.text: Article 166(1) directory; non-compliance loses protection but does not invalidate if proved made by proper authority.

anchor.surface_text: provisions of clauses 1 and 2... directory... omission... order would number enjoy immunity... but would number be... nullity... proved made by proper authority

holdings.reasoning_summary: Mode of expression formal; public duty directory; cites Maxwell and Federal Court; authentication rules allocate business.

holdings.text: Failure to specify period under s.11 makes detention illegal as prejudicial and onus undischarged.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Words 'such period as it thinks fit' require fixing definite period; indefinite repugnant to Constitution; temporary Act doesn't cure prejudice; analogies to bonds.
